repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Second Communal Irrigation
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, in terms of its contribution to poverty
            alleviation, and increased food security, and,
            sustainability is likely, although expansion of communal
            irrigation will require stronger local government
            units' (LGUs) commitment. The many lessons convey
            mainly, that small-scale communal irrigation schemes are
            cost effective, economically viable, and, may contribute to
            poverty alleviation, thus, providing communal responsibility
            is an effective way to ensure sustainable irrigation. But,
            successful communal irrigation require clear guidelines on
            the roles, and responsibilities of each stakeholder,
            including a comprehensive institution building program.
            There is the need for a national-level agreement among LGUs,
            central agencies, and the National Irrigation Administration
            - regarding financing arrangements, in particular, and, the
            respective roles, including design, construction, and,
            operation and maintenance (O&M) to be clearly defined.
            In addition, the need to implement a self-sustaining system
            for operation and maintenance, is paramount, to avoid
            dependency on Government funds. Hence, the establishment of
            earmarked O&M funds, financed from the Irrigators
            Associations' share of service fee collection, and,
            trust funds, financed from amortization payments by communal
            schemes, should be seriously considered for sustained
            communal irrigation.

5078983.majtheme: Social dev/gender/inclusion,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Second Communal Irrigation
            Development Project (CIDP II)

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objectives are to provide
            for continuity and improvements in implementation of the
            ongoing communal irrigation development efforts.  The
            project includes: (a) construction of new and rehabilitation
            and improvement of existing communal irrigation systems,
            including provision of adequate service and access roads and
            simple Irrigator Association (IA) storage facilities and
            drying floors, and erosion control measures; (b) development
            of communal IAs, including training of related National
            Irrigation Administration (NIA) staff, community organizers
            and IAs, with particular emphasis on management, financial
            and operations & maintenance aspects; (c) institutional
            strengthening of NIA in the field of communal irrigation,
            including improvement of NIA's communal accounting
            system and collection efficiency; improvement of the
            monitoring and evaluation capabilities of the Communal
            Irrigation Department; upgrading of the physical facilities
            and equipment of the Provincial and Regional Irrigation
            Offices; training of irrigation technicians and designers;
            and upgrading of NIA's ability to assess microcatchment
            hydrology; and (d) preparation and implementation of
            agricultural development plans for each communal scheme financed.
